title: Chronic Limb Ischemia
diagnosis_topic: Peripheral artery disease causing rest pain and ulceration
setup_script: A 58-year-old man with a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents with progressive right foot pain at rest and a nonhealing ulcer on his great toe. He reports worsening claudication over the past several months, now limited to one block of walking. On exam, you note an ulcer with a necrotic base on the first toe. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 140/80 mmHg, HR 85 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37 °C.
Diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on right, ankle-brachial index 0.4, ulcer with necrotic base at first toe.
Duplex ultrasound shows multilevel occlusive disease in superficial femoral and popliteal arteries; CT angiography demonstrates distal tibial runoff.
Antiplatelet, statin, diabetes optimization, and smoking cessation counseling are started.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays intervention after medical therapy
dynamic_flow.reply: Ulcer worsens and progresses to gangrene requiring amputation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery for intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan for infrainguinal bypass versus endovascular revascularization.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about indications for surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Rest pain and tissue loss are indications for revascularization.
Local wound debridement, offloading, and infection control measures are necessary.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proposes exercise therapy only
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient continues to have ischemic rest pain and ulcer progression; exercise therapy alone is insufficient.
Operative finding: occluded superficial femoral artery with poor inflow; vein graft bypass performed with improved distal perfusion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Resident should describe exposure, selection of conduit, proximal and distal anastomosis technique, heparinization, and intraoperative assessment of flow.
Balloon angioplasty and stenting performed with improved perfusion.
Long-term follow-up with ABI and duplex imaging is planned; continued aggressive risk factor control.
If revascularization fails or patient presents late with non-salvageable limb, amputation level is determined by tissue viability and perfusion.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of critical limb ischemia with rest pain and tissue loss
Initiation of risk factor modification and medical therapy
Appropriate use of diagnostic imaging to assess runoff
Timely referral for revascularization (bypass or endovascular)
Integration of wound care and infection control
Ability to describe operative technique for revascularization

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Your performance on this chronic limb ischemia scenario demonstrated You recognized the clinical presentation of chronic limb ischemia and appropriately pursued diagnostic imaging. Your management plan included initiation of medical therapy and revascularization options. You demonstrated clear communication of findings and management priorities.. Areas for improvement include Earlier recognition of the need for urgent revascularization could have improved patient outcomes. A more detailed operative description would strengthen your performance, including exposure, conduit selection, anastomotic technique, and intraoperative flow assessment. Avoid reliance on conservative measures alone in patients with tissue loss.. Suggested reading includes SCORE Curriculum: Chronic Limb Ischemia and Peripheral Artery Disease; SVS Guidelines on Management of Critical Limb Ischemia; ACS/ASE Review Manual: Operative Approaches to Infrainguinal Bypass and Endovascular Therapy
